Her fate is quickly intertwined with those of Pub and Ian as they are thrust into the middle of a mystery bigger than any they have ever known. The town is led by Mayor Jordy Darkwood, a vampire struggling with his conscience as he fights to hold things together as the politics of the old world and the new come crashing together, while his wife Mercy is hiding the fact that she is one of Pub's many mistresses. Lorlet, a local herbalist and psychic, is a confidant of Pub's, and the only female he has not been able to seduce. The underworld of Port Stoker is ruled by The Edge and his ruthless enforcer, Mr. Bates, both of whom know more of the secrets of Freeland than most. Then there are Ivy, Rose and Thorne LePlante, the triplet owners of Satiate, the towns largest brothel and gambling hall, which is a frequent haunt of Pub's. Other important characters include Favour Boulet, art gallery owner and one of Pub's frequent conquests, Wheezy Becket, Pub's landlady and owner of Becket's Books, Professor Myers Eller, expert in human mythology, and Seatta Seaut, an author whose human fiction books, The Sun Dancers,  have become all the rage. And then there is Savean, a female vampire of great mystery, power and beauty, recently returned to town from parts unknown with an agenda that will forever change Port Stoker, Freeland and all who live there.     Blood and Wine will be the first of six books in a series by the same name. Over the course of the series, many secrets will be revealed, relationships formed and tested, conspiracies will run wild and a shocking revelation will change everything and everyone. What Do I Want To Achieve?      First and foremost, I want to entertain the reader with a world unlike any they have ever seen, with characters both unique and exciting, but at the same time believable and relatable. I want to take the vampire legend and honor its history and traditions while also infusing it with new ideas of what a vampire is. In most vampire stories, humans are in integral part to the story. We seldom see how vampires act among themselves when they are not trying to seduce or devour people. In  Blood and Wine, I have crafted  a unique and well thought out world where humans do not exist. I want to immerse readers into a very detailed landscape, reimagined through the eyes of a vampire. What would a world look like where its inhabitants can never venture into the sun? I spent years creating this world, focusing on the smallest of details, and believe that I have come up with a place never before seen in literature. I have greatly enjoyed creating this place and these one of a kind characters. I hope you enjoy reading about them and come to love(and hate) them as much as I do. Who Am I?     Good question. The answer has many parts, some that are still being added as I continue to change and learn new things about myself. The important part, at least in this instance, is that I am a story teller, a crafter of lore, who has finally decided to put it all down into a series of novels and try my hand as a writer. I have written many short stories and some a little too long to be called short stories, but this only my second attempt at a novel. The first ended when I realized I didn't really care about the characters or believe in the story. That's what makes this time so different. With Blood and Wine, I have spent years thinking about this story, dissecting every part of it, reworking the ideas, throwing out the ones that didn't work and expanding the ones that did. I have created a world full of characters, some who made the cut and some who didn't and some who turned out to be totally different than who I originally thought they were. I have breathed life into this place and to me it has become real, not in the I'm crazy way, but in the way that I finally believe in what I'm writing, I care about the characters and what happens to them, even the not so nice ones and there are a lot of those.     My simple bio is that I grew up in the '70s in a small town in North Carolina. I honed my imagination in a time before technology started killing it. I was always a voracious reader, spending many hours in our towns library, always checking out the maximum amount of books. I read everything I could get my hands on, and at some point decided, I want to do that. Of course, as it often does, life got in the way and being a writer was put on the back burner. Now after a lifetime of many different careers, including over 10 years in the book selling business, and countless creative writing classes, it is time to pursue the dream, hopefully with your help.     I have been living in Las Vegas for the past 10 years and although I don't think I have ever actually met one, if vampires do exist, this is where they would live. This town has reawakened my imagination. I have met many unique individuals, some of whom have at least partially morphed into characters in my book. I have experienced what it's like to live in a place where you can actually do everything in the dark and sleep away the daylight hours. I use all of this to up the realism in the book.What's The Money For and What Do You Get?     The money raised will be used for many different things.   + to finance the completion of book one.   + to self publish book one in digital and hardcover formats   + to commission original artwork for the series   + to market the series to find a major publisher to put the series in wide release   + promotion of the seriesThe more money that is raised, will result in higher quality books published in greater quantity. Money left over will go towards book 2 in the series.     For helping to fund this project, backers will receive many great rewards depending on the amount pledged. Some rewards include digital and hardcover copies, t-shirts, a personal thank you in the acknowledgements section of the book, a chance to name a character in the book, a chance to have me personally come to your house to read the book and much more. Check out the rewards section for more details. Without your support, it may take years to get this project completed if at all. With your contributions, I plan to be finished and meet all reward responsibilities by the end of May next year, if not sooner.   Risks And Challenges     There are always risks and unexpected challenges with any project. However, I promise to do my best to meet all deadlines and to produce an enjoyable quality book in the end. I have a strong support system of family and friends to help when and where needed, plus access to contacts from my many years in the book selling business. If any unforeseen obstacles arise or plans change, I will inform all backers immediately. I will also be posting constant updates on the status of the project. Also please feel free to contact me with any questions you may have.Other Ways You Can Help I know that not everyone can contribute financially. I appreciate any amount that you can give. It all adds up.  You can also help by getting the word out about my project to as many people as possible by posting it on your Facebook page or Twitter or posting it on group pages. I can also always use more contacts in the publishing world.And Lastly     I would like to thank everyone who has taken the time to read my proposal. I hope you will be able to help out. I believe that Blood and Wine is something special and I hope that you will too once you read it. Thanks again.

story:
Die Story

Gestern, heute, morgen - wie geht man mit einem in sich kollabierenden Universum um und wie steht dieses im Zusammenhang mit dem Individuum? Der Kampf eines jungen Mannes mit der eigenen Selbstwahrnehmung in der Berliner Startup-Welt; ein Sturm, der die Welt verändern soll; ein Dorf im Osten Deutschlands, welches sich mit den Schattenseiten des Kapitalismus auseinandersetzen muss; der Selbstmord eines vielversprechenden Komponisten; oder die Geschichte von Rahel, einer jungen Frau, die vor dem Nichts steht - dies sind die Schicksale im Zentrum des ersten Bands der Genre-Mix-Reihe Metronomarchie.

2012/Alexander

Ein Sturm bewegt sich von Asien her auf Europa zu und droht den Kontinent zu zerstören. So zumindest beschreibt es ein Manuskript, welches dem Startup-Unternehmer Alexander zugespielt wird und indem er eine tragende Figur ist. Als zusätzlich noch Fotos auf seinem Instagram-Account auftauchen, auf denen er an Orten zu sehen ist, an denen er noch niemals war, gemeinsam mit Menschen, die er nicht kennt, fängt er an Nachforschungen zu erstellen und gerät tiefer und tiefer in ein Netz aus Verschwörungen.

2015/Sebastian

Um die Schließung des Glaswerks in dem Thüringischen Dorf Obergrundbach zu verhindern, entschließt sich eine Gruppe junger Arbeiter um den charismatischen Streikführer Benjamin dazu, das Werk zu besetzen. Zur gleichen Zeit kommt der Cousin des Streikführers, Sebastian, ins Dorf und wird kurzerhand in die Verhandlungen mit dem US-Amerikanischen Eigentümer eingespannt.

2018/Ezra

Krystalis, ein modernes Schloss und Campus für Hochbegabte, errichtet von Milliardärs-Zwillingen außerhalb von Berlin, in dem junge Menschen ungestört an der Zukunft arbeiten können; ein Utopia, das überschattet wird von einem Selbstmord. Das siebenundzwanzigjährige Komponistenwunderkind Ezra nimmt sich das Leben und hinterlässt einen letzten Wunsch: Sein Meisterwerk, die Krystalis-Symphonie, soll von einem Outsider abgeschlossen werden - seinem ehemals besten Freund. Als dieser nach Krystalis kommt und mit der Arbeit beginnt, ahnt er noch nicht, dass er sich bald auf die wahre Natur des Schlosses stoßen wird und auf dessen dunkle Geheimnisse.

Wie hängen diese Ereignisse zusammen? Welche Rolle spielt die mysteriöse Tomorrow Alliance? Was ist real und was sind Verschiebungen in Zeit und Raum? Metronomarchie - Buch Eins: Boys ist der Auftakt zu einer Buchreihe, die alle Ebenen der Existenz durchdringt und die Schönheit und Tragik der kollektiven menschlichen Erfahrung offenlegt.

Eine Leseprobe bekommt ihr hier.

 

Die Kampagne

Metronomarchie - Buch Eins: Boys ist der erste Teil einer neuen Science-Fiction-/Fantasy-/Gegenwartsroman-Reihe. Da der erste Band mit ca. 130 000 Wörtern bereits ziemlich umfangreich ausgefallen ist, bin ich mir sicher, dass einige Passagen über eine reguläre Verlagsveröffentlichung dem Rotstift der Lektoren zum Opfer fallen würden. Da mir aber jedes Wort am Herzen liegt, habe ich mich dazu entschloßen, eine erste ungekürzte Auflage über eine Crowdfunding-Kampagne zu finanzieren.

Die Kampagne hat nur ein geringes Funding-Ziel, da ich keine fixe Auflage drucken lasse, sondern mich nach euch Unterstützern richte, d.h.: Wenn 13 Unterstützer eine gedruckte Version wollen, dann bestelle ich 13 Stück.

Long story short: Der Roman ist abgeschlossen und wer eine erste, ungekürzte Version des Romans lesen möchte, sollte sie hier bestellen.

Die verschiedenen Versionen

Das eBook bekommt ihr bereits zum kleinen Preis. Die gedruckte Version ist etwas teurer, dafür aber sehr schön geworden - ihr werdet also die Mehrinvestition nicht bereuen. Außerdem bekommt jeder, der die gedruckte Variante bestellt, das eBook kostenlos dazu (ist ja klar).

Alle weiteren Specials seht ihr bei den Perks rechts.

 

Über den Autor

Daniel Bock, Jahrgang 1985. 

Metronomarchie ist mein erster Roman und entstanden innerhalb der letzten zwei Jahre. Wie alle Dinge, die einem wichtig sind, war die Arbeit an Buch Eins anstrengend und nervenvernichtend. Dennoch kann ich es nicht erwarten, mit Buch Zwei zu beginnen.

Finden könnt ihr mich hier und hier.

 

Risiken & Herausforderungen

Risiken gibt es bei dieser Kampagne eigentlich keine. Es kann natürlich immer passieren, dass der DHL-Laster umkippt, aber davon geh ich jetzt mal nicht aus. Das Buch ist abgeschlossen und will gelesen werden.

Wenn ihr noch fragen habt, schreibt mir einfach!

Liebe Grüße, vielen Dank für eure Unterstützung und bis bald,

Daniel

story:
World, meet Annabelle McLeod

 We are often cautioned against inappropriate behavior throughout our lives. Well-wishing parents and friends scold us for being different, advise us to get back with the program, behave. But what if the opposite of the norm is where the truth lives? This is the driving question behind my creation of Inappropriate and Annabelle McLeod. As the star of this story, Annabelle is a woman determined to buck the status quo and carve out a meaningful life beyond the bounds of acceptable behavior.  

I began work on this manuscript in 2010, with the guidance and support of my deeply talented writing group. Along the way, I have been astonished at the resiliency, grit and gusto of Annabelle. This story has cinematic elements and the settings are often grungy, bleak, and textured. The characters are flawed and jagged and profoundly human. Annabelle's family is steeped in age old regrets and resentments and she struggles to find the support she needs. She searches for meaning in the seediest places, including dodgy donut shops and grimy basements. Addictions are explored in graphic detail during her forced residence in a rehab clinic. A stroke of luck takes her to Manhattan to work as a commercial photographer and she is surrounded by a new crop of unforgettable friends and peers who have a profoundly positive impact on her. There is a dark experience at the Chelsea Hotel that threatens to shatter her forever until she returns home to her family in London, finding solace, peace, and redemption.

The Impact

My goal with this story is to illuminate the murky parts of life and ultimately show beauty in the ignored nooks and crannies of working class society. It is my deepest hope that others will find universal elements in the story and within Annabelle and emerge from this with new perspective and enthusiasm for life.

Although I have just reached the 60% mark in my manuscript, the word is already getting out and I have been gifted with tremendous support and feedback from the community. I have been invited to share Annabelle with future readers on the radio and as part of literary events around Calgary, including Flywheel at Shelf Life Books. An excerpt has already been published in Calgary's largest arts weekly, FFWD.

Here are a few of the comments I received after sharing Annabelle at a live reading event with my writing collective, TBD.

"You were the best... great composure and delivery. My fave." Conrad Ouchi

"You know, those are the moments one strives for, those universal moments of recognition, when one catches a glimpse of something beyond oneself...you really did it. I could feel it in my gut, and better yet - in my bones." Angela Dillon

If you would like to listen to an excerpt from my Flywheel reading at Shelf Life Books, you can check out Calgary Spoken Word


Win/Win

In order to complete the story, I need to spend the month of April conducting a research residence in New York, St. Thomas, and London,Ontario, the primary settings for the book. A good deal of this is to ensure geographical accuracy and also to immerse myself in the climate and energy of the these locales. I have already begun arranging interviews with key sources to ensure every technical and historical detail is accurate and compelling.
My anticipated costs are airfare, accommodation, and the cost of coffee/lunch for interview subjects.

Travel (Includes air/bus/train. Lowest pricing on all fares: $1140
Lodging (sublets/motels): $2500
Dailies (food/incidentals): $1160
 

In the unlikely event I don't raise the funds needed, I'll dig into my own pockets. For example, taking on more copywriting jobs, selling more photos, waiting on tables, if necessary. This story has momentum now, and I believe so strongly in making this happen, I would be willing to walk to New York and London to get what I need.
In the more than likely event I raise more than my budget, I'll be able to pay my sources modest honorariums in New York and London for their valuable time and insight.

Your support of my work fills my heart with firecrackers of happy and so naturally I would like to offer tokens of gratitude for your generosity. Smaller donations will receive a grateful postcard, handwritten with love, by me and sent to your home. Who doesn't love a postcard?

 Medium gifts will get a high resolution digital file of an image that evokes the night mood of Annabelle, created by yours truly. The file will be emailed to you, along with a message brimming with gratitude.

Larger donations will get a hand written letter, by me, to you. A real, genuinely crafted letter detailing the tremendous honor it is to be creating this work for you. On publication, I will send you a personalized, signed copy of Inappropriate.

The biggest donors (limit of two) will receive a signed gallery wrap, sent to your home or office of an image from my highly successful photo exhibit, Urban Textures.


Let's do this thing!

Other Ways You Can Help

Phone calls and encouraging emails mean so much to me. Feel free to send me pep talks via direct message. Follow me on Twitter and share my campaign with your pals. Add me on Facebook and hit 'like' on Inappropriate.

Share this on your blogs and send emails. Tell the world you need this story. Shout it from the rooftops. Tumblr/Stumblr me. If you're in the Calgary area, come to a reading! For me, there is nothing more fulfilling than watching how my words move you.

story:
About Us

Hi!  My Name Is Jay Davis.  

My colleagues and I are all teachers, trainers or consultants in one form or another.  In fact, one of my colleagues, Mr. Dan Valdez, is the principle author of the #1 entrepreneurial curriculum in the United States (Bauer College of Business).  Another, Mr. Randall Montalbano is (in my opinion) one of the top rated Marketing Consultants on the planet (validated by his consistent Top 5 ranking on marketingprofs.com).  I am blessed to be surrounded with many other teachers and trainers of the highest caliber.  Far too many to name here.

I have personally developed a system of learning that I believe can perpetuate a person with "average" intellect to certified "genius", simply by engaging a certain part of the brain through reading.

This requires very painstaking formatting and layout, as well as significant graphic design work to produce each full color publication, but I think that this can revolutionize the way that reference texts and educational books are written.  Perhaps even change our entire educational system.

 

The Impact

"50 Pages On..." is the merging of two problems into a single solution. 

The first problem is the fact that it is too difficult to find valid, expert level references to learn from and/or to cite for your research.  The sources that are out there are either hundreds of pages long, or if they are short, they are too generalized to gain any level of true expert comprehension, and definitely can't be used as valid reference citations for your work.  

The second is the problem of "frontal lobe numbing", which inhibits our cognitive abilities and thereby limits our intellectual prowess.  The system and format in which this series will be delivered re-sensitizes our frontal lobe and reinforces a barrier against future "numbing".  The result being that we learn much faster, comprehend complex concepts to a higher degree and retain information longer.

Our system of learning can literally revolutionize the way that reference and educational texts are written.  This could mean a total paradigm shift in academia as a whole.  Many so-called experts will be nay-sayers on our theory, so the only way to prove it is to DO IT!

NOTE: 

Reading is the fundamental tool used in formalized learning in most of the civilized world.  This is an indirect form of learning as it requires a person to recognize, analyze and interpret incoming data, then produce a corresponding (and hopefully accurate) output based on no sensory perception of the "object of focus".  The experience is totally virtual.  This system tends to be somewhat effective; however the natural learning mechanism is sensory based and no "focus relevant" senses are engaged by reading...UNLESS you access the part of the brain that associates memories and experiences that were originally gained through sensory perception!  Story tellers do this very well, and story telling is an excellent method for teaching.  The problem is that most academia based knowledge cannot be efficiently told in a story (unless you know the Ancient Egyptian Secrets).

"50 Pages On..." provides a new type of learning mechanism that engages the reader in a manner that activates that part of the brain that connects data, images, memories AND sensory perception in order to solve complex problems (cognitive reasoning).


What We Need & What You Get

This project will allow us to produce the first 3 titles of this comprehensive series that will eventually cover every subject under and beyond the Sun. About Us
Hi!  My Name Is Jay Davis.  
My colleagues and I are all teachers, trainers or consultants in one form or another.  In fact, one of my colleagues, Mr. Dan Valdez, is the principle author of the #1 entrepreneurial curriculum in the United States (Bauer College of Business).  Another, Mr. Randall Montalbano is (in my opinion) one of the top rated Marketing Consultants on the planet (validated by his consistent Top 5 ranking on marketingprofs.com).  I am blessed to be surrounded with many other teachers and trainers of the highest caliber.  Far too many to name here.
I have personally developed a system of learning that I believe can perpetuate a person with "average" intellect to certified "genius", simply by engaging a certain part of the brain through reading.
This requires very painstaking formatting and layout, as well as significant graphic design work to produce each full color publication, but I think that this can revolutionize the way that reference texts and educational books are written.  Perhaps even change our entire educational system.
 
The Impact
"50 Pages On..." is the merging of two problems into a single solution. 
The first problem is the fact that it is too difficult to find valid, expert level references to learn from and/or to cite for your research.  The sources that are out there are either hundreds of pages long, or if they are short, they are too generalized to gain any level of true expert comprehension, and definitely can't be used as valid reference citations for your work.  
The second is the problem of "frontal lobe numbing", which inhibits our cognitive abilities and thereby limits our intellectual prowess.  The system and format in which this series will be delivered re-sensitizes our frontal lobe and reinforces a barrier against future "numbing".  The result being that we learn much faster, comprehend complex concepts to a higher degree and retain information longer.
Our system of learning can literally revolutionize the way that reference and educational texts are written.  This could mean a total paradigm shift in academia as a whole.  Many so-called experts will be nay-sayers on our theory, so the only way to prove it is to DO IT!
NOTE: 
Reading is the fundamental tool used in formalized learning in most of the civilized world.  This is an indirect form of learning as it requires a person to recognize, analyze and interpret incoming data, then produce a corresponding (and hopefully accurate) output based on no sensory perception of the "object of focus".  The experience is totally virtual.  This system tends to be somewhat effective; however the natural learning mechanism is sensory based and no "focus relevant" senses are engaged by reading...UNLESS you access the part of the brain that associates memories and experiences that were originally gained through sensory perception!  Story tellers do this very well, and story telling is an excellent method for teaching.  The problem is that most academia based knowledge cannot be efficiently told in a story (unless you know the Ancient Egyptian Secrets).
"50 Pages On..." provides a new type of learning mechanism that engages the reader in a manner that activates that part of the brain that connects data, images, memories AND sensory perception in order to solve complex problems (cognitive reasoning).

story:
Can castaways be redeemed? Are we bound by our circumstances or our past? What is the true power of love and does it really cover an abundance of Sin? What is really the consequence of Sin?
 
Greetings, my name is Amanda Reaves, and I have been working on the Christian Fantasy world of Astria Legends for over ten years. I desire to empower our future generations with the knowledge that they can make a difference both in their own lives and in the lives of others. I want to teach them that every decision that they make has the power to affect those they will never come in contact with and can last lifetimes. The Dawn of Unity Series is a fantasy, something that young adults as well as adults can get into, but it is also a tool. A tool that shows young adults that no matter how old they are, what they have done, what they have been through, their background, race, how they were brought up or what others have said about them, that it is never too late to make a change.

Synopsis of the Series:

Welcome to the Astria Galaxy, a world filled with myths, legends and creatures of all different backgrounds and species. High above them, between the galaxy and the heavens, lies Astria; the world of living breathing color. Angels to some, protectors to others, the Astrians live as one with the universe, becoming anything it needs. Created by the Exalted One, they are the only protection between the galaxy and Sin. Some will overcome, while some give in. Their choices effect the overall UNITY; a delicate creature whose influence could destroy the galaxy. It is then that the biggest lessons are learned...

 
If you would like more information about the book, please feel free to visit the website at http://astrialegends.com
 

What I Need

The first novel in the Dawn of Unity series: Genesis has already been published and over 100 copies have been sold. Exodus, which is the second book in the series (despite being published first) didn't have a great turnout. Now I am taking it and giving it an entire makeover.

The Exodus II project will not only produce a second edition to Exodus, but also have a full animated show as part of the novel's release party. The movie above is just a sample of the animation that I am working on.

Your contributions will help make it all possible by helping to pay for publishing, editing, costs for putting the release show together, and advertising.

What You Get

I am giving away tons of neat perks! Not only can your get a personalized signed copy of Exodus when it is published, but you can get a copy of Genesis as well (if you dont already have it).

Also, for the FIRST time EVER I am offering SKETCH Journals. One of a kind journals with a colored sketch of ANY Astria Legends Character of your choice! (Shown above are actual handmade journals...yours will have a hand sketch of the character)

There is also the chance to snag a minor character in the story to name whatever you want (I reserve to right to deny any offensive name). And there are more goodies listed in the perks!

 

Dream and Believe

Ten years in the making, such a long time spent on a dream. It has been a journey, both for me as well as all those who dwell in Astria Galaxy... and the journey has only just begun!
 
Help me make it possible! If you can't contribute, that's perfectly ok, I only ask that you pray and spread the word to whomever you can. Every little bit counts.

story:
My name is Sarah Shipley and I’m bringing Off Kilta Matilda™ to life because I’m passionate about STEM and I’m passionate about girls loving the bodies they are in.

I wanted to create a book that blended these topics and taught girls that math can be fun and to be proud of your image and accomplishments.

 

I’ve been working on this project for over 10 years! Off Kilta Matilda™ has quite the history.

(Irv meeting Madeline) 

The History

When my husband was stationed in Afghanistan in 2006 my daughter Madeline was born. He wrote stories for me to read to Madeline. I always wanted to bring a story to life so I rewrote the best one and created my first draft ...but kids, jobs, and a few startups got in the way. I took a few classes on illustration and even tried to make a claymation version of Off Kilta Matilda™. Needless to say, claymation is very hard.

 

In 2016, I found a wonderful Illustrator Eric Stykel, and we were off and running!

I created my first prototype, got friends and family involved, asked for advice from hundreds of experts and decided to go for it.

(the team) 

 

The history of this book is not as exciting as what I hope the future will be.

 

In my role as a mother, I overhear a lot of kids talking. I hear phrases like, “Math is hard” or “I’m not good at math.” As adults, we know that self talk is important. What you say becomes reality.

I am making my best effort to give children a positive vocabulary about math and science. I am making my best effort to get more girls excited about math and really excited about how beautiful math can be.

 

This campaign has a few goals, none of them are small.

I’ve got a huge vision for Off Kilta Matilda™ and the Prime Number Club™.

Imagine a Prime Number Club™ in every school!

A group of kids can read the book, start the club, and meet once a week to solve math problems. This kind of positive peer group reinforcement is a great way to make math skills stick.

Publishing this book is the beginning of the vision for Off Kilta Matilda™.

We are working on a three book series for Off Kilta Matilda™. The first book is how Matilda starts the Prime Number Club™. The second book will focus on how prime numbers are stronger together and focus on teamwork. The third book will focus on the prime number mysteries and codebreaking.

In addition to this series, we want to create animated educational shorts featuring Off Kilta Matilda™ and her friends and work towards a computer game that will educate kids (and parents) on math. 

(one of our coloring sheets) 

When you back this campaign you are helping create a future where girls embrace math. Where numbers are fun and not at all scary.

Please back the project and help launch Off Kilta Matilda™ and the Prime Number Club™.

What are people saying? Well, Check this out! 

 

Check out the press.

 

Why do we need funding? 

Off Kilta Matilda™ has been a bootstrapped project from the start. I've put thousands of dollars and hours into bringing this to life. I’ve paid the designer, the videographer and artists and filed all of the copyrights and trademarks. I’ve done the market research, a landscape analysis and met with teachers, mathematicians, business owners and publishers. We have secured printing and all of our perks used during this campaign are sourced in the USA. All of our work has  been sourced locally in Kansas City. Our designer, videographer, editor, and office are all here in KC. We seek funding because we want to grow quickly! 

We have goals, and then we have stretch goals.

When we raise approximately $6,000, we can print 3000 Off Kilta Matilda™ books and design book #2.If we reach $10,000, we can design complete one of our shorts.  

If we raise more, we go further. We have business plans from $5000 to $525,000. 

If you are interested in learning about the project, the plan or how to partner drop me a line.  

We have the capacity and the ability to scale very quickly.

 

Why should you believe me?

I’ve been in marketing and communications for over 20 years. I’ve created and managed successful campaigns, launched three startups (all still in business), won quite a few awards, and have a great track record at finding product market fit. I’m launching this crowdfunding campaign to help raise capital and raise awareness about kids and STEM. 

I’m creating the campaign because the world needs it.

Math is beautiful, fun and should not be presented as scary or hard.

Please share this campaign with your family and friends and help bring Off Kilta™ Matilda and the Prime Number Club™ to life today! 

Thanks a bunch! 

-Sarah and the entire team. 

 

This has been a family affair! The photo below is when the kids came with me to a pitch night for new business. We found out that evening hopped in the car and went.



(this is a photo of our first prototype and a draft of the book)

story:
Hi, we're The Wild Word...

An online magazine for passionate people, run by a rag-tag bunch of visionary, unashamedly left-wing enthusiasts for the written word.

For two years, The Wild Word (or TWW as our affectionate insiders call it) has delivered a great monthly online magazine. In that time, we've had dozens of our articles picked up by the Huffington Post and our parenting columnist was recently featured on US morning TV. We've published fiction writers who've gone on to publish novels and anthologies, and one of our artists-in-residence won a prize for a piece he created especially for his TWW residency.

In short, it's great content.

And it's all produced and made available for free, with no advertising. We're a true independent magazine, powered by volunteer energy.

It takes a lot of time and hard work to produce. But we do it because we believe our voices matter – and that by speaking up, we represent the people who share our perspective, and those whose voices can't be heard.The start of the dream...

TWW was started by Kusi Okamura. Originally from Ireland (you can tell by her name), where she worked in journalism, these days Kusi is a Berlin-based mother and entrepreneur. After her children were born, Kusi started dreaming about a platform for arts and issues, a place where people's creativity would be on show and their voices could be heard. So she started it from her back room. Along the way she figured out how to build the website, and sought out great writers, artists and musicians and convinced them to come on board.

Erin O'Loughlin (who isn't Irish, despite the name) submitted some fiction to one of the first issues, and over coffee with Kusi she found herself irresistibly drawn to Kusi's enthusiasm and vision. She became Associate Editor, then Fiction Editor, and has never looked back.

We cover the issues we care deeply about, with monthly columns on the environment, feminism, politics, social justice, parenting, and mental health - with a generous side helping of arts, poetry and fiction.

Now, we're asking our readers to give a little something back, so that we can continue to produce great content, and to launch our next passion project - a small publishing press, to help writers we love become published authors.

Here's what they are saying about us

Working with The Wild Word has been a tremendous pleasure. The journal is beautiful, relevant and ambitious; Kusi is a subtle editor and a perceptive, enthusiastic visionary. I so look forward to what she does next.

Donna Steiner
Writer and artist

Before encountering the opportunity on The Wild Word's website, I'd never heard of an online Artist in Residency (o-AiR).  What a bright beam-of-an-opportunity it provided me -- into corners of poetry I'd not yet explored.  For example, while poetry shadows have been on my mind, the o-AiR was where and when I first discussed them.  While many artists have likely enjoyed a traditional place-based residency, Kusi Okamura and her team have opened a whole new opportunity in e-space to dance, prance and cavort.  Yes! 

Hiram Larew
Poet

It's all about the give and take...

Ever heard someone say "I'd do it even if I didn't get paid?" Well that's how we feel about the magazine. Except we actually don't get paid.

Our aim (okay, dream) is to make the magazine a self-supporting platform, one where we can pay our contributors. For now, we'll keep putting out the good stuff, month after month.

Meanwhile, we've got bills to pay.

- Like the cover artist for the upcoming novel we're publishing, a genre-bending cyberpunk, facebook-punk (we're coining the term), noir, LGBTQ novel that the world needs to read.

- And print copies of our poetry and fiction anthologies from the first year, for all the poets and writers who have entrusted their work to us (for free, y'all. These amazing artists let us have their work, even though we couldn't pay them. We really owe them a book).  

- And the production of the upcoming ebook from TWW columnist Jami Ingledue whose parenting column has garnered many fans for her from-the-heart style.

- And all the coffee and co-working cafes that go into getting the magazine out each month.

It's a fairly modest amount. We're not asking for the moon (but if anyone has one to donate, we wouldn't say no).

In return, we're offering rewards like:

- Undying Thanks - to anyone who donates €1. We will eventually shuffle off this mortal coil, but our thanks will remain forever.

- Eternal Thanks - not just our thanks for all eternity, but your name in the thanks section of The Wild Word. And you know that's priceless. (But we've put a price on it, which is €5.)

- Our Love & Resistance buttons, with artwork from the magazine's talented artist Ashling Keever. Because there's never been a better time to love and resist. For every €10 donation, we'll pop one in the post to wherever you are.

- For €15, you get eBook versions of our first poetry anthology, or if you prefer, our first fiction anthology. Featuring all the work we've published in the first year of the The Wild Word, these will be the first in an annual series.

- But why choose, when for €20, you can get both the poetry and the fiction eBook. Check out the way the covers fit together to make a set. They'll look so pretty on your kindle.

- For a €30 donation, you'll get both the eBook and the printed version of either the poetry or the fiction anthology.

One of our biggest loves at The Wild Word is the chance to nurture writers, and that's why we're offering two Writer's Perks.

For €10, we will offer you a full short story critique. Get feedback on what's working and what needs work, from the people who know.

For the bargain price of €100, we are offering full book manuscript critiques. This is a service that would normally cost at least €400. We will critique the characters, plot and story development of your masterpiece, whether it's in progress, or already completed.

And of course, we'll keep filling the magazine with great poetry, fiction, art and commentary every month, whether you donate or not. But please donate.

The Impact

Your donations will make a big difference. They will help us to set up the publishing press, publish our first three books, and build a small shop on the magazine website to sell them.

This is the seed money that will help the magazine become self-supporting and profit-generating.

This is the kick-start for the magazine as a small business and not just a passion project.

We really believe in these projects and they're already underway. But a little help from our friends will go a long way.

Risks & Challenges

Whenever you rely on volunteer effort, there's the risk that talent will be poached. We've already had other publications approach some of our writers. Luckily, they believe in The Wild Word as much as we believe in them.

  • Your donations will mean that we'll be on our way to setting ourselves up as self-supporting and profit-generating. So that eventually we'll be able to give our writers some payment and not just gratitude.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute right now, that doesn't mean you can't help. Some other ways to support The Wild Word are:

  • Get the word out about our campaign - the more people who know, the more people who might donate, or might drop by the magazine to read something. Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word!
  • Drop by the magazine and read something. Sign up for our monthly newsletter.
  • Share our articles - help us spread our stories deeper into the wilds of the internet.  
  • Submit something - we're always looking for great content. Check out our calls for fiction and poetry submissions, and the monthly themes, and send us your best work.

Here's just a taste

story_txt:
Hi, we're The Wild Word...
An online magazine for passionate people, run by a rag-tag bunch of visionary, unashamedly left-wing enthusiasts for the written word.
For two years, The Wild Word (or TWW as our affectionate insiders call it) has delivered a great monthly online magazine. In that time, we've had dozens of our articles picked up by the Huffington Post and our parenting columnist was recently featured on US morning TV. We've published fiction writers who've gone on to publish novels and anthologies, and one of our artists-in-residence won a prize for a piece he created especially for his TWW residency.
In short, it's great content.
And it's all produced and made available for free, with no advertising. We're a true independent magazine, powered by volunteer energy.
It takes a lot of time and hard work to produce. But we do it because we believe our voices matter – and that by speaking up, we represent the people who share our perspective, and those whose voices can't be heard.The start of the dream...
TWW was started by Kusi Okamura. Originally from Ireland (you can tell by her name), where she worked in journalism, these days Kusi is a Berlin-based mother and entrepreneur. After her children were born, Kusi started dreaming about a platform for arts and issues, a place where people's creativity would be on show and their voices could be heard. So she started it from her back room. Along the way she figured out how to build the website, and sought out great writers, artists and musicians and convinced them to come on board.
Erin O'Loughlin (who isn't Irish, despite the name) submitted some fiction to one of the first issues, and over coffee with Kusi she found herself irresistibly drawn to Kusi's enthusiasm and vision. She became Associate Editor, then Fiction Editor, and has never looked back.
We cover the issues we care deeply about, with monthly columns on the environment, feminism, politics, social justice, parenting, and mental health - with a generous side helping of arts, poetry and fiction.
Now, we're asking our readers to give a little something back, so that we can continue to produce great content, and to launch our next passion project - a small publishing press, to help writers we love become published authors.
Here's what they are saying about us
Working with The Wild Word has been a tremendous pleasure. The journal is beautiful, relevant and ambitious; Kusi is a subtle editor and a perceptive, enthusiastic visionary. I so look forward to what she does next.
Donna SteinerWriter and artist
Before encountering the opportunity on The Wild Word's website, I'd never heard of an online Artist in Residency (o-AiR).  What a bright beam-of-an-opportunity it provided me -- into corners of poetry I'd not yet explored.  For example, while poetry shadows have been on my mind, the o-AiR was where and when I first discussed them.  While many artists have likely enjoyed a traditional place-based residency, Kusi Okamura and her team have opened a whole new opportunity in e-space to dance, prance and cavort.  Yes! 
Hiram LarewPoet
It's all about the give and take...
Ever heard someone say "I'd do it even if I didn't get paid?" Well that's how we feel about the magazine. Except we actually don't get paid.
Our aim (okay, dream) is to make the magazine a self-supporting platform, one where we can pay our contributors. For now, we'll keep putting out the good stuff, month after month.
Meanwhile, we've got bills to pay.
- Like the cover artist for the upcoming novel we're publishing, a genre-bending cyberpunk, facebook-punk (we're coining the term), noir, LGBTQ novel that the world needs to read.
- And print copies of our poetry and fiction anthologies from the first year, for all the poets and writers who have entrusted their work to us (for free, y'all. These amazing artists let us have their work, even though we couldn't pay them. We really owe them a book).  
- And the production of the upcoming ebook from TWW columnist Jami Ingledue whose parenting column has garnered many fans for her from-the-heart style.
- And all the coffee and co-working cafes that go into getting the magazine out each month.
It's a fairly modest amount. We're not asking for the moon (but if anyone has one to donate, we wouldn't say no).
In return, we're offering rewards like:
- Undying Thanks - to anyone who donates €1. We will eventually shuffle off this mortal coil, but our thanks will remain forever.
- Eternal Thanks - not just our thanks for all eternity, but your name in the thanks section of The Wild Word. And you know that's priceless. (But we've put a price on it, which is €5.)
- Our Love & Resistance buttons, with artwork from the magazine's talented artist Ashling Keever. Because there's never been a better time to love and resist. For every €10 donation, we'll pop one in the post to wherever you are.
- For €15, you get eBook versions of our first poetry anthology, or if you prefer, our first fiction anthology. Featuring all the work we've published in the first year of the The Wild Word, these will be the first in an annual series.
- But why choose, when for €20, you can get both the poetry and the fiction eBook. Check out the way the covers fit together to make a set. They'll look so pretty on your kindle.
- For a €30 donation, you'll get both the eBook and the printed version of either the poetry or the fiction anthology.
One of our biggest loves at The Wild Word is the chance to nurture writers, and that's why we're offering two Writer's Perks.
For €10, we will offer you a full short story critique. Get feedback on what's working and what needs work, from the people who know.
For the bargain price of €100, we are offering full book manuscript critiques. This is a service that would normally cost at least €400. We will critique the characters, plot and story development of your masterpiece, whether it's in progress, or already completed.
And of course, we'll keep filling the magazine with great poetry, fiction, art and commentary every month, whether you donate or not. But please donate.
The Impact
Your donations will make a big difference. They will help us to set up the publishing press, publish our first three books, and build a small shop on the magazine website to sell them.
This is the seed money that will help the magazine become self-supporting and profit-generating.
This is the kick-start for the magazine as a small business and not just a passion project.
We really believe in these projects and they're already underway. But a little help from our friends will go a long way.
Risks & Challenges
Whenever you rely on volunteer effort, there's the risk that talent will be poached. We've already had other publications approach some of our writers. Luckily, they believe in The Wild Word as much as we believe in them.
Your donations will mean that we'll be on our way to setting ourselves up as self-supporting and profit-generating. So that eventually we'll be able to give our writers some payment and not just gratitude.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute right now, that doesn't mean you can't help. Some other ways to support The Wild Word are:


Get the word out about our campaign - the more people who know, the more people who might donate, or might drop by the magazine to read something. Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word!

Drop by the magazine and read something. Sign up for our monthly newsletter.

Share our articles - help us spread our stories deeper into the wilds of the internet.  

Submit something - we're always looking for great content. Check out our calls for fiction and poetry submissions, and the monthly themes, and send us your best work.

story:
Hey! I'm Oli Carew, aka Monsieur Odyssey. A couple of years ago I wrote a children's picture book, hosted an online illustration competition, and with the help of the crowdfunding community self-published my first title, The Incredible Chapore. It actually did pretty well- selling a few thousand copies, and winning a self-publishing book award. So I thought I'd give it another go!

My second book is called The Lucky Book. It's about a boy called Stanley, and the power of positive thinking. I wrote the book, and a talented young man called Matt Hunt worked with me to produce the illustrations. It's for 3-6 year olds (but could probably stretch a year either side of that!).

The book is pretty much ready to go, so now I'm looking to raise some money to print a small, exclusive run of 200 copies. So if you're looking for the perfect Christmas present, or just fancy supporting, then please do make a contribution- please just bear in mind that the campaign is only running for 15 days so that I can print and deliver the books just in time for Christmas.

story:
I'm Egle Gerulaityte, a traveler, a writer and a journalist. I'm passionate about discovering strange and obscure places and cultures, and as a journalist, I always want to know all there is to know about the local life. All around the world, people are so ordinary and extraordinary at the same time - and I love telling their stories, because it's the stories that connect us!

South America is so much more than just an exotic destination. Indigenous Quechua women are discovering feminism, Andean shamans are falling in love with motorcycling, contemporary jazz is taking over Colombia and human rights activism is sweeping across Argentina.

At the same time, South America is home to lost legends of vanished tribes, Patagonian ghost stories, Andean myths, and Caribbean melancholy. Tales from South America is a mix of the everyday, the curious, and the fantastical.

Publishing this book means the world to me. And to the people in the book, this means the world will get to hear their stories! 

If you back this project, not only you'll get an electronic or printed copy of the book, but you'll also help the actual people in the book - I've decided to donate 5% of the book sales to the people and families I met on the road.

Want to have a quick look before you back it? Download the first chapter of "Tales from South America" HERE!

What I Need & What You Get

To make Tales from South America a reality, I need:

- $1,500 to finish the research and revision of the book

- $2,000  to work with a professional editor

- $3,500 to publish & print the book

- $500 to cover shipping costs for sending out books 

- $600+ in IndieGoGo platform costs and fees

Backing this project, you'll get a whole bunch of unique perks including:

- the digital or printed version of the book

- a postcard from South America

- a motorcycle tour in Ecuador

- an opportunity to meet the actual people in the book

- a chance to be featured in the book yourself!

The Impact

Tales from South America: Everyday Life, People, and Legends has a simple but important message: around the world, ordinary people's lives can be made extraordinary through storytelling. 

If this project overfunds, I would love to include numerous illustrations in the book, produced by local South American artists!

As a freelance writer and journalist, I have successfully published these stories, among many others:

- Guna Yala: Islands Where Women Make All the Decisions, BBC Travel

- Venezuelan Refugee Crisis: A Glimpse, Egle On The Road

- Miraculous Hill of 100,000 Crosses, BBC Travel

- Last Leather Tanners of Ecuador, BBC Travel

I have also created and still edit an online magazine for women motorcyclists, Women ADV Riders, aimed at women who love travel, adventure, and motorcycling.

My first book, Testimony of a Vagabond - a predecessor to Tales from South America - was published in Lithuania in 2017.

I'm pouring my heart and soul into this book, and I hope you'll enjoy meeting all the incredible local people from Peru, Bolivia, Argentina, Chile, Ecuador and Colombia!

There are some risks involved. Independent self-publishing can be a complicated process, but I am confident that with your support, I can make this book a reality.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with your friends, families and coworkers, and post it on social media.

Let's make this happen!

story:
Last Pony on Earth was completed several years ago, but it left an indelible legacy on apocalyptic and post-collapse fiction that demands to be printed. The story is already complete, and can be read here. For years now I've been getting requests to do a print version of this book, and the time has finally come to fulfill that request. I've learned a great deal about printing and distribution during my first project, and I hope to be able to use that knowledge to bring this excellent story to everyone.

The Details

With this project, we're setting out to get a deluxe hardcover print run of the apocalyptic fiction story Last Pony on Earth. Thanks to the lessons I learned during the Message in a Bottle print campaign, and the physical realities of this story (it isn't nearly as long), I will be printing two version of this book: a full color hardcover, and a black and white softcover. This way I expect LPoE to be within-reach of almost anyone interested in grabbing a copy.

 

 

The print will also contain approximately 12,000 words of original fiction not to be published outside these physical prints, meant to connect the narrative of LPoE to the events of the sequel story, Founders of Alexandria--written in the original style and with new illustrations to go along with the story.

As you might expect, Zutcha will be reprising his role as the artist of the series.

The funds raised will be used as follows:

  1. The proof copies of the book and coverblock.
  2. Original cover and illustrations.
  3. Printing and distribution of the books themselves.
 

The book will contain minor corrections to the text made since the original publication, but otherwise will be identical to the story currently available on Fimfiction.net, save for the original content at the end.

Those who want to support the author a little could spring for an autographed copy, or support at the higher "custom chapter" tier, where I will write approximately 2,000 words of original PaP fiction about the subject of your choice. So long as it's in-universe, it need not be during this time period or even about Alex, unless you want it to be.

A word on custom chapters: The Last Pony on Earth narrative is a story much smaller in scope than my last book, and as a result I won't be able to add custom chapters into the physical print. These chapters will likely be published online in the Bedtime Stories anthology, or somewhere else if I believe they would fit well.

Risks & Challenges

I've learned a great deal about the systems involved in printing and distribution since my last project. I've learned real shipping costs, and the hardcover print proof has already been delivered (with the softcover on its way).

The only real risk I can think of is that the illustrations drawn for Last Pony on Earth were fairly small in pixel density as they were created spontaneously for the web. Here's a photograph of the print of how the illustrations actually look so you can judge for yourself, but I think they look great.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? That's fine! Obviously I'm not printing this story for the money--it's all about getting something awesome in hardcover. I don't expect anyone who isn't interested in hardcover books to buy this one. If you'd rather just read the story, you can do it for free right now. 

If you'd like to help but you aren't interested in the book, feel free to share this campaign with anyone you think might want to buy a copy. Like anything in printing, this project gets easier the larger the volume we make.

story:
About Caleb, The Entrepreneur

Caleb is a very awesome 9 year old. At age 5, his parents started to teach him the basics about money and finance. His first exposure was going door to door in the community selling his healthy snacks. That first summer, he and his mom, went door to door, for about an hour and Caleb made $50 for his hour of work. He didn't even know how to count the change but his mom helped him out. :)

He learned a few valuable lessons that summer:

  1. Some people are mean. They shout and say no and close the door on you.
  2. Don't let mean people discourage you. Just tell yourself to move along to the next person.
  3. There are good people who are happy and willing to support.


His first experience, helped him to learn a basic principle about money and about relating to people. And he loved the experience. He also loves to watch Warren Buffet cartoons to learn some basic principles about money.

 

About Caleb, The Author

Caleb wanted to write his own book after he saw his mom, also an author, with her book. He felt inspired. He wanted to have his own book for kids and so his dream was born. Caleb's parents have worked to try to foster and nurture the dream of this little guy. And in this nurturing, the Moshe Money and Elias Froggy book series was born.

Book 1 (Launched December 2012)

 

Book 2 (Launched November 2013)

 

Book 3 (Launched March 2014)

Here Why You Should Fund Caleb.

Your funding will help Caleb to continue the production on books 4, 5 and 6. Caleb's dream to have his book series become a successful series to teach kids like him about life in a fun and entertaining way. Our dream is books 4 to 6 completed by Summer of 2015 with your help. Caleb's book series are a good investment as his past record demonstrates he is dedicated to his project being a success. You really have got a proven winner with him!

Caleb is diligent in his book development, he:
  • Works hard to get his story written
  • Tells the illustrators what his characters should look like and approves the final drawing designs
  • Colours the characters so the illustrators will have an idea of his concept for the character clothes
  • Bugs his production coordinator about when his book will be out
  • Reads the proof copy when printed to check for typos or mistakes.

If this was a job, Caleb's resume would say, two years experience as a small Canadian author. :)  You know he can do it!

Your Funding Will...

Your funding will help Caleb to continue the dream. He will be able to create the books #4, #5, and #6 and get them illustrated and produced. Caleb's dream to have his book series become a successful series to teach kids like him about health, money, and life will be a reality with your help.

Because there are many costs associated with a book like illustrators, layout and design people, technology people to make it a kindle version, and others, We're asking for your help to meet the book creation financial obligations. Plus, Caleb wants his book to be a mobile game in the future (his wishlist).

  • Goal 1: 1 more book completed and launched: By mid of Q1 2015
  • Goal 2: the next book completed and launched: By mid of Q2 2015
  • Goal 3: the next book completed and launched: By mid of Q3 2015

These three goals are only possible if we have the funds to make it happen via your generousity.

    Goals

    It has been a challenge for Caleb but he is having fun. Caleb really wants to help more kids and so we have some stretch goals which we will make happen if we exceed our funding goals.

    Caleb has as a major goal to develop his Moshe Monkey and Elias Froggy into a mobile app game. Money raised will go first towards books 4 to 6. Then any extra money beyond what is needed to cover the costs of the books, will go into a pool for projects such as adding more activities for kids on his website, creating an App version of his books, making the game app and more.

    • A: $1500
    • B: $3000 * 1 book funded
    • C: $4500
    • D: $6000 * 2 books funded
    • E: $7500
    • F: $9000 * 3 books funded
    • G: Above $9000 * Stretch Goal: Extra funding for his book app
    • Beyond G: You're all super people. A dream can be realized.


    Caleb with Author, Karen Ranzi

     

    Help Caleb by Getting The Word Out

    Help us get the word out by sharing this campaign on facebook or tweeting about it. We really appreciate your help. You can even make a cute meme with something like, "I funded Caleb's Book series."

    Have an awesome day!

    If you help out by funding, I know that people love to also leave a comment but if I could ask you to create a meme to leave a photo comment. Create the meme at http://images.mosheandelias.com and them paste the link to it or share your meme on facebook. Check out some memes on the site since it was launched in December 2013.

It has been a challenge for Caleb but he is having fun. Caleb really wants to help more kids and so we have some stretch goals which we will make happen if we exceed our funding goals.

Caleb has as a major goal to develop his Moshe Monkey and Elias Froggy into a mobile app game. Money raised will go first towards books 4 to 6. Then any extra money beyond what is needed to cover the costs of the books, will go into a pool for projects such as adding more activities for kids on his website, creating an App version of his books, making the game app and more.

A: $1500
B: $3000 * 1 book funded

C: $4500

D: $6000 * 2 books funded

E: $7500
F: $9000 * 3 books funded

G: Above $9000 * Stretch Goal: Extra funding for his book app

Beyond G: You're all super people. A dream can be realized.

Caleb with Author, Karen Ranzi

 
Help Caleb by Getting The Word Out
Help us get the word out by sharing this campaign on facebook or tweeting about it. We really appreciate your help. You can even make a cute meme with something like, "I funded Caleb's Book series."
Have an awesome day!If you help out by funding, I know that people love to also leave a comment but if I could ask you to create a meme to leave a photo comment. Create the meme at http://images.mosheandelias.com and them paste the link to it or share your meme on facebook. Check out some memes on the site since it was launched in December 2013.

story:
PAPER AND INK LITERARY ZINE

Paper and Ink is a UK based literary zine that promotes good writing, presented on paper and printed in ink. Designed and edited by myself (Martin Appleby), the first issue launched in March 2013. Just seven different writers and artists featured in that first issue and it has gone from strength to strength ever since, growing in both size and reputation with each issue.
Paper and Ink is a physical format only zine, so you won't find it available to read online or on an e-reader and I am very proud of that fact. The only drawback to that is that printing each issue costs money. I paid for the printing of the first five issues out of my own pocket, and I make no profit from sales. Any financial renumeration is ploughed back in to printing the next one. However, my financial situation is a little tight at the moment so I am unable to stump up all of the necessary funds. That is why I need your help to get issue six across the finish line.

ISSUE #6

Issue #6 will be our biggest and best yet. The theme is childhood and features poetry, short stories, flash fiction, illustrations and photography from over forty different writers and artists from all over the world.

The finished zine will be A5 in size, 40 pages in length and printed on 80g white paper, with the cover printed on 170g off-white card. I am aiming for the print run to be 150 copies, but obviously the more money that can be raised, the more copies we will print. 


REWARDS

Obviously I am not expecting anyone to hand over their hard earned money without getting something in return, so if you look over to the right hand side of this page you will see some pretty awesome perks. The kind of items that no self respecting lit fiend would want to live another day without...

Get exclusive high quality A4 prints of the awesome 'Lion-O vs Optimus Prime' cover art by illustrator Marie Enger.

Get exclusive 'F**K KINDLES, READ ZINES' t-shirts and badges (pins).

If you're quick you will also find some signed goodies from friend of PAPER AND INK and cult underground author, Joseph Ridgwell.


If you just want to pre-order a copy of Issue #6 to be in the first mail out then that is cool, too. 

If you're suffering financially yourself at the moment and can't afford to chuck a few quid our way then please, please help by sharing this campaign on social media.

That's about all I've got to say really. Please help if you can, there are some really fantastic writers in this issue whose voices deserve to be heard by the masses! Help us make that happen...

story:
Imagine the story of the birth of a state, a nation, and even an empire, as told through the biography of the man who proved, and sometimes disproved, many "facts" of that story. Dr. William M. Kelso has spent a half century rediscovering, excavating, and interpreting archaeological sites of sweeping global and historical importance. Primary among these is his most recent find: the original 1607 James Fort site—the birthplace of Virginia, the United States, and, arguably, the British Empire. Phoenix Summoned: Resurrecting Lost Worlds from the Ashes is the working title of his biography I'm writing, and it explores this storied man's life, and along the way reveals the origins of one of the world's greatest empires, and the genesis of what became the most powerful nation in history. (The graphic below is for illustration only--not the real cover. The image is from Microsoft's free clipart collection, and is supposed to be a phoenix.)

I'm Dan Smith, and thirty years ago while earning the B.A. in anthropology and archaeology and working on my first archaeological dig, I met Bill Kelso when he visited our site in southwestern Virginia, and then stayed up most of the night playing music with other bluegrass enthusiasts on our crew. Even that early in his career our crew leader counseled us to watch him—he was going to be a luminary in the field. And he is.

In 2005 I took Bill's field school at Historic Jamestowne and stayed for a month as an intern after the six-week school. Leaving for a year and a half to finish coauthoring Jamestown Colony: A Political, Social, and Cultural History (ABC-CLIO, 2007), I returned to his crew in 2007 and have worked there since then. Because of my work and conversations with him, and the research, writing, editing, and proofing I do for him, he enthusiastically agreed (with his characteristic humility) with my idea of writing his biography.

I anticipate the biography to range between 90,000 and 120,000 words, and I'm planning on completing it in the first quarter of 2015. I'm trying to raise $10,000 through this Indiegogo campaign to help pay for the expenses involved in the research, writing, and materials needed for the book (archaeologists at Jamestown earn very little!). These expenses include:

- travel to the various sites Bill worked on to do research and take photos (including Jamestown, Monticello, Colonial Williamsburg, Poplar Forest, Wormslow Plantation, Fort King George, Fort Jackson, and other sites in Virginia and Georgia)

- buy stock photos from the sites' owners

- artwork, editing, printing, copying

- buy and mail the perks

- allow for Indiegogo and PayPal fees

- use my weekends and evenings writing instead of working a second and third job!

More Details

Phoenix Summoned is a story of adventure and discovery, as told through the life of the man who is living it. For fifty years, Bill Kelso has been rediscovering and excavating archaeological sites that reveal the origins of Virginia, the United States, and the British Empire. He has spent years digging under the grueling sun and extreme temperatures—both high and low—which have, indeed, turned him into the tough, physical man one would expect. But in addition to his extensive fieldwork, he also has become an accomplished author, historian, and spokesperson for his life's work—rewriting the history books by finding and interpreting what many people only speculate about. He has written and lectured extensively, earning numerous awards and honorary degrees, including the CBE, or Honorary Commander of the Order of the British Empire—Britain's second highest civilian honor. Phoenix Summoned explores this remarkable man's life, and as his contributions to archaeology and history are revealed, the facts and myths about the birth of the United States and the British Empire are exposed through the archaeological evidence—the proof in the ground—he has brought back to light and life. This biography relies on not only extensive research, but on my years of field experience and discussions with Bill Kelso.

Because this biography is based on science and history, it will appeal to scholars and practitioners in those areas. Archaeology necessarily incorporates aspects of many disciplines, including geology, biology, hydrology, chemistry, marine science, meteorology, dendrochronology, physics, and even forensics, to name a few. Dr. Kelso's biography extends beyond those "hard" sciences, however, because his is a story of adventure and discovery, and of mystery and wonder. Children are not the only ones with gleams in their eyes and whispers or gasps of excitement when something not seen in 400 years, or even thousands of years at some of his sites, is discovered and carefully extracted from its hidden resting place. Older folks visit with Dr. Kelso at his digs, too, and even they are awed by the findings and are sometimes overwhelmed to be meeting the man who has become such a legend in his field.

A bit about me (since Indiegogo said to include this!)

While earning the B.A. in anthropology and archaeology, with minors in geology and French, I worked as an archaeologist on prehistoric sites in southwestern Virginia (where I first met Bill Kelso). Those studies and experiences gave me a solid foundation in what is the background of this biography. Earning the M.A. in foreign affairs at the University of Virginia taught me advanced research and writing skills. After completing the Master's I began work on a one-volume encyclopedia about Bill's premier site. To gain a better understanding of the subject, and return to one of my favorite kinds of work, I took Bill Kelso's archaeological field school at Jamestown and then left to finish Jamestown Colony, which includes entries about Bill Kelso's life and the archaeology at Jamestown. Since returning to Bill's archaeology crew in early 2007, I've continued to learn about Bill's life and contributions by working with him daily—digging with him during the field season, and researching, writing, and editing for him when not excavating. (Below is a picture of the Jamestown Rediscovery field crew. I'm third from the right.)


Although I have advanced training and experience in writing nonfiction, I realized that to appeal to a wide audience, a narrative based in science and history would have to be told in a style other than just a statement of facts, analysis, and conclusions. Properly told, Bill Kelso's life's story will be an intelligent, compelling adventure that will appeal to not only a highly educated audience, but to a non-academically oriented one as well. To this end, I completed courses in creative writing, resulting in a substantial body of fiction in both prose and poetry, including a 20,000-word core for a future novel. I hope to have this published about a year after Bill's biography.

So, if you can see the importance of telling the story of the many contributions Dr. Kelso has made to the archaeological and historical record of the earliest years of what became the United States and the British Empire, please consider helping support these efforts. I'll be forever grateful, and the world will know the exciting story of a legendary life!

story:
When people share stories from their past, they're sharing parts of themselves. The intimacy of a good story is worth more than a thousand pictures rather than the other way around. It is why the book is almost always better than the movie. This intimacy is key to Nostrum Fabula.

ABOUT NOSTRUM FABULA "OUR STORIES"

Starting in mid-April I'm heading out on a year-long bike tour around the United States to gather stories from the people I meet along the way. The stories I will collect are Nostrum Fabula. Nostrum fabula is Latin for "our stories" and these words are meant to be a basic representation of the project. Nostrum Fabula will take form as a daily blog, with a new story each day, and at the end of  the year a print version will be in the works.

Nostrum Fabula is more than just a collection of stories. It is a way for people to connect with others they may never have gotten to otherwise. These stories are a much more intimate glimpse into others' lives than the pictures that flash around us every day. It is my hope that these stories will create a greater sense of community among those that read them, highlighting our similarities rather than the differences we are often so quick to see in others.

HOW YOU CAN HELP

So here's the deal. My campaign goal of $7200 represents my monthly expenses for the entire year, half of which is food. I've cut my expenses as much as possible (e.g. selling my car) and have $4000 of personal funds set aside for the year. Meeting my campaign goal means I can upgrade my gear, enhancing both the project and personal comfort (i.e. making my bike/biking better). It also means more of my time and energy can be put directly into this project, rather than making money to support it along the way. Any extra funds will go towards working on the print version at the end of the year.

Besides money, there are plenty of other ways to help.

1. Share. If you like what I'm doing share it with as many people as you can. 

Spend a little extra time sharing and swapping stories with either someone new or someone you wish to know better.

2. Help on the road. I'm gonna be camping and couch surfing my way across the country which requires all sorts of support in itself. This includes but is not limited to: places to sleep(indoors and outdoors), food support (I love food), and advice.

3. Moral Support. Any encouragement, prayers, and thoughts are always welcome and much appreciated.

Please feel free to contact me via e-mail with questions, concerns, feedback, and/or encouragement. I would love to hear from you.

story:
Selected as the winner of the ArtReach Youth Arts Pitch Contest 2014 – Community Arts Projects and Productions Black Like We: Troubleshooting the Black Youth Experience, is an anthology that seeks to address systemic issues faced by Black youth through the lens of their lived experience. Despite this success, we still need you! We are looking to produce an e-book, provide mentorship workshops for youth, outreach in classrooms, and youth contributors with honorariums and copies of the printed book, showing them that their contributions are valued and that they can get paid for their creative work. We need $5,000 to do it!

Blacks have the highest percentage of youth in Canada and one quarter of Canadian-born Black youth don’t feel Canadian, since Blacks are the target of 42% of hate crimes in Canada. Such alienation can lead to mental illness and substance misuse.

For 78% of Black students, learning more about their culture or race would make learning more interesting, and for 56% improve their performance in school. With a 40% drop-out rate among Black students, our community needs solutions.

 Overrepresented in Canadian prisons, Black inmates have requested reintegration program materials address their race and cultural background as these have significant impact on their entering prison. While Corrections staff disagreed, Black Like We argues that going to prison is not a uniform experience.

In the book, you’ll hear from Caribbean and continental African youth, with experiences of abuse, incarceration, foster care, and trauma. 

Though our aim is not just to publish a book, but rather to provide a resource.  With our first book, Basodee: An Anthology Dedicated to Black Youth, our goal was expression. We had no idea its impact until we started getting requests to speak to students.

Available in libraries, Basodee made the Recommended Book List at the Toronto Public Library and Open Book Toronto. With your support and by building on connections like these, we will get Black Like We into the hands of many of the youth who need it.

In providing contributors with mentorship and skills to facilitate workshops where they share their stories, we want to impart the idea that professors aren’t the only ones writing books for classrooms, but young people too.

A second book targeted to students, will enable the formation of a self-sustaining group, funding workshops delivered in remote communities through book sales, and help make Black Like We part of the curriculum.

Funds raised in this campaign will go towards honorariums, workshops, and conducting outreach with the books to youth who need it.

Black Like We creates a unique learning model, with youth voices empowered to write solutions. Black feminist Chimamanda Adichie, warns against the danger of the single story. Please give generously to this campaign which seeks to give youth an opportunity to tell their stories. In the words of Alice Walker, “Our people are waiting.”



Fiona Raye Clarke is the winner of the ArtReach Youth Arts Pitch Contest 2014 – Community Arts Projects and Productions and editor of the book Basodee: An Anthology Dedicated to Black Youth published in 2012 by General Store Publishing House. She has a degree from the University of Toronto in Philosophy, is a law graduate of the University of Southampton, and a Master of Laws student at Osgoode Hall Law School at York University. She is a dynamic speaker and facilitator of a weekly writing workshop for youth through Toronto WordSmiths and is a storyteller with Passages to Canada and a dedicated volunteer of the Ontario Black History Society. Her passions include art, writing, and resistance, and youth empowerment through community arts. She has published with Who’s Who in Black Canada, IFreeCan, and in various student legal publications in the United Kingdom.
